title: 114_hr2332
content: The Act titled "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a Transformational Infrastructure Competitive Grant Program. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a transformational infrastructure competitive grant program under the Secretary of Transportation. Grants can be awarded to state governments, local governments, transit agencies, and port authorities for eligible projects like highway or bridge improvements. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" creates a grant program for infrastructure projects impacting metropolitan areas, regions, or the entire United States. Eligible projects include highway or bridge improvements under title 23, and public transportation projects under chapter 53 of title 49. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a grant program for infrastructure projects, including seismic retrofit projects for bridges, road realignments, public transportation projects, passenger or freight rail transportation projects, port infrastructure investments, aviation infrastructure projects, and water infrastructure projects. Coordination is required for these projects. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a grant program for infrastructure projects, including seismic retrofit projects for bridges, road realignments, public transportation projects, passenger or freight rail transportation projects, port infrastructure investments, aviation infrastructure projects, and water infrastructure projects. Coordination is required for these projects, with specific requirements for water infrastructure projects. Eligible entities must submit applications to the Secretary for grant consideration. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a grant program for infrastructure projects, including seismic retrofit projects for bridges, road realignments, public transportation projects, passenger or freight rail transportation projects, port infrastructure investments, aviation infrastructure projects, and water infrastructure projects. Eligible entities must submit applications to the Secretary for grant consideration, with criteria for financial commitments included in the application process. Regulations specifying grant award criteria will be issued by the Secretary within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will use specified criteria to make competitive grants under subsection (b), including considerations for financial commitments from non-Federal sources. The Federal share of project costs cannot exceed 100 percent. Grants under subsection (b) will be distributed geographically in an equitable manner. The Federal share of project costs assisted with a grant under subsection (b) cannot exceed 100 percent. Grants must be distributed equitably, address urban and rural needs, promote veteran employment, and ensure a percentage is spent through small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. The grant funds must comply with Title 40 requirements and Buy America provisions, ensuring that project costs are distributed equitably and support small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. The funds for a project under this Act must use iron, steel, and manufactured goods produced in the United States, with exceptions allowed if it's not in the public interest, not available in sufficient quantities, or increases project costs by more than 25 percent. The Secretary may waive the requirement to use US-produced iron, steel, and goods if not available in sufficient quantities or quality, or if it increases project costs by over 25%. Justifications for waivers must be detailed and published. This subsection must align with US international agreements. The Secretary can waive the use of US-produced iron, steel, and goods if not available in sufficient quantities or quality, or if it increases project costs by over 25%. Justifications for waivers must be detailed and published. The program established under subsection (a) must prioritize transparency and accountability, ensuring grants are used efficiently, information on grants is made public, and progress on funded projects is reported to Congress annually. The Department of Transportation must provide information on grants made under subsection (b) and report progress on funded projects to Congress. The Secretary must coordinate with other federal departments to streamline environmental reviews for projects receiving grants. $985 billion is authorized for grants under the program established in subsection (a). Authorization of Appropriations: $985 billion is authorized for grants under the program established in subsection (a) for fiscal years 2016 through 2020. The Secretary shall allocate 85% of the funds for projects described in subsection (c)(1)(A), (B), or (C), 2% for projects in subsection (c)(1)(D), and 4% for projects in subsection (c)(1)(E). In subsection (c)(1), funds are allocated as follows: 2% for projects in subparagraph (D), 4% for projects in subparagraph (E), and 9% for projects in subparagraph (F). SEC. 3. NATION BUILDING HERE AT HOME FINANCING INITIATIVE. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, will establish a Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The Treasury Secretary may issue bonds up to $300 billion, with specific terms and conditions, to fund transportation projects. Bond proceeds will be transferred to the Secretary of Transportation for project implementation. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue bonds with specific terms and conditions to fund transportation projects. Proceeds from the bonds will be transferred to the Secretary of Transportation for program implementation. The Secretary of Transportation must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment, detailing the transportation needs of the United States for the next 20, 30, and 50 years.
